ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Spanish grammar, vocabulary, increased fluency in speaking/presentations/etc. Also heavy emphasis on cultural knowledge
Speaking, listening, and reading of Spanish at an intermediate level.
Spanish in more tenses than 110, culture and literature as well.
I really improved my Spanish by learning more tenses and grammar rules, expanding my vocabulary, and becoming more comfortable speaking the language.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Strengths-- clear syllabus, well organized class, engaging instructor. Weaknesses-- an extreme amount of work and occasionally harsh grading. Although I liked that we spent so much time on cultural knowledge, it sometimes felt like there was not enough time for grammar/vocabulary practice in class

Strength: clear instruction for tests and assignments
Weakness: less clear instructions for class activities and projects

The course is structured very well to facilitate student learning. All the homework assignments served a purpose, whether it be to improve listening, writing, or grammar/vocabulary. I really appreciated that there were so many resources to practice for exams, and that we had multiple attempts to finish homework assignments -- I learned a lot more this way. I was also consistently engaged throughout the live seminar. I can't really think of any weaknesses -- this is a great option for fulfilling the language requirement, and I enjoyed it more than 110.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I definitely appreciated the two asynchronous days.
I think the canvas assignments all worked really well for virtual learning.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, if genuinely you want to learn Spanish or need a language credit.
Yes, the Spanish courses at Yale are great.
Yes, it is an essential course for understanding Spanish language and culture.
Since you're probably taking this class for the language requirement, I would say that this is a very good class, especially if you can take it with Juliana.

Spanish is such a beautiful language and I definitely think everyone who is interested in learning Spanish should take it! I would just say be prepared to get frustrated with the Spanish department occasionally. The class is incredibly demanding, often for no apparent reason. The course was not flexible at all. Even for simple things, such as an extension, my professor would require a dean's note. There is no reason why the course shouldn't offer extra credit, especially during a pandemic. Besides those frustrating moments and aspects, I do feel like I learned a great deal of Spanish. However, I do think I would have learned more if the course had been set up in a more compassionate way.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
